I know! When a star dies, either 2 things happen. If its 5 times bigger than our sun, it becomes a neutron star. If its 8 times bigger than our sun, it becomes a black hole. The core stays but the outer layers tug in and bounce off the core and that EXPLODES THE STAR AT SO HIGH FORCE, THE TEMPERATURE REACHES OVER A BILLION DEGREES, AND VAPORIZES EVERYTHING IN ITS PATH! In the neutron star scenario, the outer layer bounce compresses the core into a 27 mile ball of pure neutron. In the black hole scenario, the outer layer bounce generates SO MUCH COMPRESSION, THAT LAWS OF PHYSICS BREAK DOWN AND IT COLLAPSES IN ON ITSELF INTO A BLACK HOLE! And, the star leaves a huge nebula that would later collapse and become another star, a nebula is like an egg, waiting to hatch and burst into another star.

---- > Why does a star explode?:
As the star's core becomes filled with heavier fused elements, the star gets bigger and it's lighter elements (hydrogen and helium) are positioned in the outer shell. At some point, the loss of mass in the outer shell means there's not enough compression to cause fusion /emit photons. Some hydrogen and helium would be left un-funsed.
... The fusion of silicon into iron causes the core to shrink and get heavier. The remaining gas "falls" and is compressed into a smaller area. The increased compression of remaining gases and increased gravity on the iron results in increased compression and fusion . The star emits photons and expels its fused elements.
.... The explosion may also be related to electron degeneracy pressure.... electrons push against each other to resist collapse (of the lead core). If electrons push to resist gravity, perhaps the other fused elements also push against the heavier mass of iron (or both push outward).
... ie: the electron bubble mass in front of the heliosphere where it meets interstellar space.

I'm pretty sure there IS an explanation for how a "ball of iron and collapsing gas" triggers a supernova. For a star over 25 solar masses, the collapsing outer layers falling onto the core cause it to implode enough that it shrinks beyond the schwartzchild radius, causing it to become a black hole. For really really massive incredibly rare stars above 90 solar masses, the entire star will just quitley collapse into a black hole, with the force of gravity from the mass being so great that the implosion is too fast for any of the star's material to have the possibility of rebounding. However in slightly less massive stars, the force of gravity, while strong enough to convert the dead core into a black hole, is too weak to counteract the sheer energy carried by the neutrinos produced from the core collapse, and that sheer energy causes the outer layers of the star to rebound in the superova.

If people would just stop using that silly expanding-ring animation (0:36) - it doesn't happen that way! An expanding uniform shell of gas or anything else looks like a donut to us because we're looking through the most material at the edges and the least at the center. That's just simple geometry. We could look at it from any other angle and it would still look like an expanding donut for the same reason. But there's NO viewing angle that would show an expanding donut in a non-perpendicular plane. Film-makers get this wrong all the time, but I expect better from a genuine science video.
